question_text:
You have a Fabric F32 capacity that contains a workspace. The workspace contains a warehouse named DW1 that is modelled by using MD5 hash surrogate keys.
DW1 contains a single fact table that has grown from 200Â million rows to 500Â million rows during the past year.
You have Microsoft Power BI reports that are based on Direct Lake. The reports show year-over-year values.
Users report that the performance of some of the reports has degraded over time and some visuals show errors.
You need to resolve the performance issues. The solution must meet the following requirements:
Provide the best query performance.
Minimize operational costs.
Which should you do?

answers.A: Change the MD5 hash to SHA256.
answers.D: Modify the surrogate keys to use a different data type.

discussion:
Enable V-Order: This should be your first step as it directly targets performance improvements with minimal cost.
Consider the following before deciding to disable V-Order:
Microsoft Fabric Direct Lake mode depends on V-Order.

The best answer is D â€“ modify the surrogate keys to use a different data type.

Using MD5 hash keys (large 16â€“32 byte values) causes memory and performance issues as the fact table grows. Switching to integer (INT/BIGINT) surrogate keys reduces memory usage, speeds up joins, and improves storage efficiency.

Other options (like SHA256, increasing capacity, or using views) donâ€™t fix the root problem â€” the inefficient data type. Integer keys are the best practice for performance and scalability.

B. Increase the capacity

Would improve performance but increases costs, violating the requirement to minimize operational costs.

C. Enable V-Order 

V-Order is an optimization in Fabric Warehouses/Lakehouses that orders data column-wise for better compression and query performance.
Specifically designed to boost Direct Lake performance.
Cost-neutral (storage optimization, not compute scaling).

Best fit here.

Enable V-Order: reshape parquet files (optimizing its). So, performance should be better, with option B (increase capacity) we have more costs which is one of the question requirement.

F2 <> F3 300 milions row.... Increase capacity is needed

An F32 SKU in Microsoft Fabric has a limit of 10 GB of memory per semantic model and can handle 300 million Direct Lake rows per table

F32 supports:

300 million rows per table
40 GB model size on disk
10 GB max memory
Your fact table has 500 million rows, which exceeds the supported limit for F32 in Direct Lake mode.

This mismatch can cause:

Visual errors
Slow performance
Query failures or memory overflows

If you're using Direct Lake and your table exceeds the row or memory limits of your SKU, increasing capacity is necessary to ensure stability and performance.
V-Order is still a great optimization, but it wonâ€™t help if youâ€™re over the SKU limits.

Bullshit question, the V-Order is turn-on by default. But the question still ask about this :(

On a table with 500 million rows covering data from multiple years, the main cost is not the JOIN operation but scanning the huge fact table for the relevant dates â€” so V-Order will make more sense than changing the primary key from MD5 to SHA256.

B is the correct answer. V-order is enabled by default; if you disable it, you can't turn it enable again.

Option: A (Change MD5â†’SHA256)
